newsitem.title: UK: Britain's television firms sign up for digital TV.
newsitem.headline: Britain's television firms sign up for digital TV.

text.p: The BBC and Britain's 15 Independent Television companies on Tuesday confirmed plans to launch digital television services.
The ITV companies will join with Channel Four, Britain's other commercial channel, in applying for the two digital multiplex licences reserved for them.
The ITV firms, which include Carlton Communications Plc and Granada Group Plc, are looking at plans for new national and regional services and expect to unveil these by the end of this year.

"Digital television will offer our viewers widescreen pictures and high quality sound, new TV channels and the prospect of interactive services as well," Leslie Hill, chairman of the ITV Association said in a statement.
The BBC said it would launch free-to-air digital terrestrial television services, taking up its guaranteed place on a digital terrestrial multiplex, which are a bundle of digital channels.
There will be four other multiplexes which will be advertised and auctioned off next month by the Independent Television Commission.
Licences for these should be granted next summer.
Digital broadcasting technology provides scope for more channels than the current transmission process allows.

The BBC said its digital service would offer viewers BBC 1 and BBC 2 in widescreen format, a 24 hour BBC news service, additional programmes, data and interactive services, including extra regional and educational programmes.
